recommend.title: Defiant, Trump Laments Assault on Culture and Revives a Bogus Pershing Story
recommend.full_text: WASHINGTON â Despite ongoing rebukes over his defense of white supremacists, President Trump defiantly returned to his campaignâs nativist themes on Thursday. He lamented an assault on American âculture,â revived a bogus, century-old story about killing Muslim extremists and attacked Republicans with a renewed vigor.Hours after a terrorist attack in Spain, Mr. Trump recalled a debunked event in which Gen. John J. âBlack Jackâ Pershing supposedly killed Muslim rebels in the Philippines by shooting them with bullets dipped in the blood of pigs, which Muslims are forbidden to eat. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in Barcelona, where the driver of a van crashed into a busy tourist boulevard, killing 13.âStudy what General Pershing of the United States did to terrorists when caught,â Mr. Trump tweeted , spreading a mythical story even as he again accused the news media of being âFake Newsâ in another tweet . âThere was no more Radical Islamic Terror for 35 years!âAs when he trafficked in the same unproven legend during the presidential campaign, Mr. Trump ignored the conclusions of historians, who repeatedly have said it did not happen. Additionally, his claim that Pershing ended terrorism in the Philippines for 35 years is refuted by the violence that continued for decades after the rebellion that ended in 1913.Mr. Trump also appeared in peril of losing support from key Republicans he will need to advance his agenda in Congress. Senator Bob Corker, the Republican chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, questioned the presidentâs âstability,â and Senator Tim Scott, the only black Republican in the Senate, declared Mr. Trumpâs moral authority is âcompromised.âMr. Corker, a sober voice on foreign policy and a frequent ally of the Trump administration, bluntly questioned the presidentâs ability to perform the duties of his office.âThe president has not yet been able to demonstrate the stability, nor some of the competence that he needs to demonstrate in order to be successful,â Mr. Corker told reporters. He said Mr. Trump had not âappropriately spoken to the nationâ about Charlottesville, Va.Mr. Scott, of South Carolina, insisted that he would not âdefend the indefensibleâ when it came to the presidentâs comments about âboth sidesâ in Charlottesville being responsible for the violence last Saturday .âWhat we want to see from our president is clarity and moral authority,â Mr. Scott said in an interview with Vice. âAnd that moral authority is compromised when Tuesday happens â thereâs no question about that,â he said, noting the presidentâs angry remarks to reporters this week in Manhattan, where Mr. Trump criticized the âalt-leftâ while abandoning earlier condemnations of the Ku Klux Klan and neo-Nazis.Earlier in the day, Mr. Trump made clear that he has no intention of stepping back from his assertions about the Charlottesville rally that have drawn widespread condemnation. In three tweets, Mr. Trump defended Civil War-era statues, using language very similar to that of white supremacists to argue the statues should remain in place.On Twitter, Mr. Trump called it âfoolishâ to remove statues of Robert E. Lee and Stonewall Jackson and mused that monuments to George Washington and Thomas Jefferson would be next. âSad to see the history and culture of our great country being ripped apart with the removal of our beautiful statues and monuments,â the president wrote.And as he faced a new round of bipartisan denunciations, Mr. Trump also lashed out at two senior Republican senators who have been unsparing in their criticism during the past week.The president accused Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, of âpublicity seekingâ and said that Mr. Graham had uttered a âdisgusting lieâ when he said â accurately â that the president had equated the white nationalist protesters in Charlottesville with the counterprotesters who were there to oppose them.âHe just canât forget his election trouncing,â the president said of Mr. Graham, who waged a losing bid against Mr. Trump for the Republican presidential nomination. âThe people of South Carolina will remember!âMr. Trump also called Senator Jeff Flake, Republican of Arizona, âtoxicâ and âWEAK on borders, crime and a non-factorâ in the Senate. He praised Mr. Flakeâs Republican primary race opponent.There was new evidence on Thursday that the political crisis created by the presidentâs Charlottesville remarks was having an effect on Mr. Trumpâs business. The Cleveland Clinic announced it was pulling out of a 2018 fund-raiser at his Mar-a-Lago club in Palm Beach, Fla., and the head of the Palm Beach Chamber of Commerce urged businesses not to host events there.The American Cancer Society, which had planned to hold its 2018 gala at Mar-a-Lago, announced it, too, would change the venue, citing its âvalues and commitment to diversity.ââIt has become increasingly clear that the challenge to those values is outweighing other business considerations,â the group said in a statement.The White House announced that Mr. Trump had decided to cancel plans to assemble a Presidentâs Advisory Council on Infrastructure. The decision to abandon the business group came a day after a revolt among industry leaders on two other advisory panels forced the president to disband them.And Carmen de Lavallade, a dancer and choreographer who will be honored by the Kennedy Center in December, announced on Thursday that she will forgo the related reception at the White House.âIn light of the socially divisive and morally caustic narrative that our current leadership is choosing to engage in, and in keeping with the principles that I and so many others have fought for, I will be declining the invitation to attend the reception at the White House,â Ms. de Lavallade, 86, said in a statement .Even so, White House officials said Mr. Trump was in good spirits on Thursday as he continued a working vacation at his estate in Bedminster, N.J. He dined with Richard LeFrak, a longtime friend, at the presidentâs golf course, according to a person briefed on the dinner.Mr. Trump also held meetings with Gov. Rick Scott, Republican of Florida, and Linda McMahon, the head of the Small Business Administration. But both events were closed to the news media, depriving the president of any further ability to engage in another back-and-forth with reporters.Within his administration, his chief of staff, John F. Kelly, was said to be deeply frustrated and unsure how to contain his boss. And pressure mounted on Gary D. Cohn, the director of the White House National Economic Council, who is Jewish and had privately expressed dismay about the presidentâs remarks.Unconfirmed reports that Mr. Cohn was about to resign prompted a statement from a White House official âNothing has changed. Gary is focused on his responsibilities as N.E.C. director and any reports to the contrary are 100 percent false.âFor the president, Thursday was a return to themes that were last on display in the weeks and months after he won the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 9, 2016.During that period, he praised dictators like Saddam Hussein as effective counterforces on terrorism and declared his support for enhanced interrogation techniques that have been outlawed as a form of torture. âTorture works,â Mr. Trump said in South Carolina that month.That was the same month that Mr. Trump first alluded to a legend â thoroughly debunked by numerous historians â about Pershing, then governor of the Moro Province in the Philippines, and his use of pigâs blood.Mr. Trumpâs remarks about the Civil War statues were also an echo of his campaign, and are not unlike sentiments in the South that the monuments and Confederate history reflect âheritage not hateâ â a phrase commonly used by groups like the Sons of Confederate Veterans.âTo those 70 million of us whose ancestors fought for the South, it is a symbol of family members who fought for what they thought was right in their time, and whose valor became legendary in military history,â Ben Jones, a former Democratic congressman from Georgia, wrote in an opinion piece in The New York Times in 2015.Critics say the presidentâs remarks reflect a dangerously sanitized view of a war to uphold slavery and destroy the union. And they say the comparison with the Founding Fathers is entirely off base Unlike the Southerners who helped found the country, the issue with Civil War monuments is that they honor people who took up arms against the United States, at least in part, to maintain slavery, critics say.Mr. Trump saw it otherwise. âThe beauty that is being taken out of our cities, towns and parks will be greatly missed and never able to be comparably replaced!â he tweeted.Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter .Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/us/politics/trump-charlottesville-confederate-statues.html?partner=bloombergCredit MICHAEL D. SHEAR and MAGGIE HABERMAN

recommend.title: How the Media Captured Charlottesville and Its Aftermath
recommend.full_text: The âUnite the Rightâ rally in Charlottesville, Va., that exploded into chaos and violence that culminated in the death of a 32-year-old woman, ended in a matter of hours.The onslaught of media reports about Saturdayâs demonstration by white nationalists and its fallout, however, has stretched on for days. And there are few signs it will stop anytime soon.Indeed, some of the coverage itself has become news â or at least commanded the internetâs fleeting attention. There was a horrifying still photograph of the violence, a chilling documentary video, and of course, a series of defiant tweets from President Trump that continued into Thursday.And then there was Tuesdayâs news conference â a combative give-and-take between the news media and Mr. Trump, which Kyle Pope, the editor and publisher of the Columbia Journalism Review, described as âa moment thatâs going to have a legacy.ââTrump has already forced several moments of reckoning on journalists,â Mr. Pope said. âWhat happened this weekend is another one of these seminal moments, another step in this very odd progression.âTaken together, the frenetic, disjointed ways the most striking media moments from Charlottesville and its aftermath unfolded and went viral â across many mediums and at lightning speed â seems emblematic of the way we consume news today.So, in case you missed them amid the weekâs many stories , weâve compiled a few of the most memorableAs tensions mounted around Charlottesvilleâs Emancipation Park on Saturday, Ryan M. Kelly stepped onto the sidewalk. Photographing Saturdayâs rally was to be his final assignment for the The Daily Progress newspaper in Charlottesville; he had accepted a job as the digital and social media coordinator at a brewery, where, as he noted on Twitter, he would âget paid to geek out about beer.âLong story short new job, new town, new beers does this mean I have to retire my usage of #partylikeajournalist ? pic.twitter.com/dqU9s4fk4V â Ryan M. Kelly (@RyanMKellyPhoto) July 31, 2017Then a Dodge Challenger came screeching past Mr. Kelly. It plowed into a crowd of people in what Attorney General Jeff Sessions would later call an âevilâ act of domestic terrorism that would leave one woman, Heather D. Heyer, dead and injure at least 19 other people.âOut of instinct, I began taking photos,â Mr. Kelly wrote in an account for the Columbia Journalism Review . âI just brought the camera to my eye and just mashed the shutter down.âThe image he captured â of a man frozen in midair before a fall, of the Challenger barreling through more victims in its path, of shoes having been knocked off their wearersâ feet â was republished widely by news outlets across the country.Other indelible images would emerge throughout the weekend.Trump defended torch-wielding white supremacists as having protested "very quietly" https//t.co/SQ8jnKkVah pic.twitter.com/5do9fGdWYG â BuzzFeed (@BuzzFeed) August 15, 2017But Mr. Kellyâs picture was quickly deemed â The photo from Charlottesville that will define this moment in American history .â[Video "Charlottesville Race and Terror" from VICE News Tonight on HBO. Watch on YouTube. ]With menacing music in the background, a pitch-black screen turns aglow by fire. White men marching with torches chant, âYou will not replace us!âThen, for the next 20 minutes or so, Elle Reeve, correspondent for âVice News Tonight,â guides viewers through the weekendâs events â including from her place embedded among the white nationalist leaders who helped organize the demonstration.âI think that a lot more people are going to die before weâre done here, frankly,â Christopher Cantwell, a man identified in the episode as a white nationalist, said Sunday after the rally had resulted in three fatalities. His opponents, he said, âwant violence, and the right is just meeting market demand.âThe unvarnished look at the alt-right and its leaders, which aired Monday on HBO, struck a chord with the public. By Thursday afternoon, a Vice News spokeswoman said that the episode had received more than 36 million views across all platforms â including HBO, Facebook and YouTube.This Vice News Documentary from Charlottesville Is Horrifying https//t.co/dnFpg7NBQx via @Esquire â J.K. Rowling (@jk_rowling) August 16, 2017CNN hailed the Charlottesville coverage as a â breakout moment â for Vice News.âI knew we had something pretty unique and pretty horrifying,â Josh Tyrangiel, the Vice executive overseeing news, told the network.By Tuesday morning, President Trump returned to his favorite social media platform, Twitter, to share a cartoon of a train running over a person with a CNN logo covering the head.The tweet was deleted minutes later and a White House official said it had been posted inadvertently.Mr. Trump took to Twitter again Wednesday to repost other peopleâs messages that assailed the mainstream media and congratulated a Fox News program for pulling in good ratings.Watching MSM you would have no idea @realDonaldTrump clearly, unambiguously & repeatedly condemned the bigotry & violence in Charlottesville â Harlan Z. Hill (@Harlan) August 14, 2017Nothing that Mr. Trump tweeted on either day would garner him as much attention as what he said on Tuesday night.At an event at Trump Tower where he expected to discuss infrastructure, Mr. Trump asked for questions â something his aides, including his new chief of staff, John F. Kelly, had not expected.We had been told Potus wasn't doing questions. He chose to overrule staff â Maggie Haberman (@maggieNYT) August 15, 2017Photographs quickly surfaced of Mr. Kelly, looking grim, as he listened as reporters call out questions and Mr. Trump respond by blaming â both sides â for the deadly violence in Charlottesville.Soon, media outlets were collecting images of Mr. Kelly and analyzing his facial expressions.Among the most popular images was one shot by freelance photojournalist Al Drago, who was on assignment at Trump Tower for The Times. By Wednesday, a tweet he sent of the photo had been shared more than 2,600 times.In a telephone interview Wednesday night, Mr. Drago said he had been taking photos of the president with different lenses when he looked to his left and saw Mr. Kelly with his arms crossed, staring intently at Mr. Trump.âI started shooting a couple photos of him and he started to look down a little more,â Mr. Drago said of Mr. Kelly. âIt was a pensive stare that helped show the mood of the news event we were in.âPeople can draw their own conclusions about what Mr. Kelly was thinking, the photographer said, but âwhen you see his body language like that, you know somethingâs up.âDuring what The Times described as a âwild, street-corner shouting match of a news conference ,â Mr. Trump defended those who had gathered to protest the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee in Charlottesville, criticized âalt-leftâ groups that he claimed were âvery, very violentâ and questioned whether the movement to pull down Confederate statues would lead to the desecration of memorials to George Washington and Thomas Jefferson.[Video President Trumpâs news conference on race and violence in Charlottesville, as seen on NBC on Tuesday. Watch on YouTube. ]Mr. Pope, the Columbia Journalism Review editor, said that although the news conference was âmessyâ and âuncomfortable at times,â it was âappropriate to the momentâ and a template for reporters moving forward.âIf someone is saying something that is demonstrably false, we donât have the obligation to let it unspool; we have the right to stop it,â he said.âI saw a guttural, emotional reaction from reporters to the news conference in a way I havenât seen before,â he added. âThere was something unleashed on both sides that is new.âAs evidence, Mr. Pope pointed to stories by The Times and The Washington Post about Mr. Trump's remarks that garnered attention for their bluntness.Astounding lede in the paper of record, with the headline "Trump Gives White Supremacists an Unequivocal Boost." https//t.co/XMPZUCT2Q7 pic.twitter.com/CH6EvKNuqC â Eric Geller (@ericgeller) August 16, 2017CNN, meanwhile, has not shied away from labeling Mr. Trumpâs remarks as âoff the railsâ in banners that stretch across the television screen. As the network cut away from Mr. Trumpâs news conference on Tuesday, the anchor Jake Tapper reacted simply by saying âWow.âEven some right-leaning television hosts could not hide their surprise. On Fox News, Kat Timpf said, âIâm still in the phase where Iâm wondering if it was actually real life.â Co-hosts of the networkâs show âThe Specialistsâ shook their heads. And later on Fox News, the commentator Charles Krauthammer said, âWhat Trump did today was a moral disgrace.âOn his Fox News show, Tucker Carlson came to the presidentâs defense, arguing that Mr. Trump had âfired back at the mediaâ before discussing famous historical figures, including Jefferson and Plato, who owned slaves.And by Tuesday night, any of Mr. Trumpâs other supporters looking for guidance on how to react were in luck. A copy of the talking points the White House sent out to Republicans in Congress was leaked .These are the talking points the White House sent out to Republicans in Congress tonight "The President was entirely correct." pic.twitter.com/Mcdy53fRRI â Molly Ball (@mollyesque) August 16, 2017Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/business/media/charlottesville-media-trump.html?partner=bloombergCredit MATT STEVENS

recommend.title: A Deal Breaker for Trumpâs Supporters? Nope. Not This Time, Either.
recommend.full_text: For Parson Hicks, a health care finance executive who supports President Trump, this past week has felt a little like dÃ©jÃ  vu. Mr. Trump says something. His opponents howl and then predict, with certainty, a point of no return.The last time this happened, she said, was in October with the notorious âAccess Hollywoodâ recording of Mr. Trump talking lewdly about women. His opponents were sure he was finished. His supporters knew better.âLetâs be honest, the people who are currently outraged are the same people who have always been outraged,â said Ms. Hicks, 35, a lifelong Republican who lives in Boston. âThe media makes it seem like something has changed, when in reality nothing has.âIt was a week of incessant tumult, when Mr. Trump tumbled into open warfare with some in his own party over his statements on the violence in Charlottesville, Va.; business executives abandoned his advisory councils ; top military leaders pointedly made statements denouncing racism in a way he did not; and his embattled chief strategist, Stephen K. Bannon, stepped down . But around the country, Mr. Trumpâs supporters â and, according to many polls, Republicans more broadly â agreed with his interpretation of a swirl of racially charged events and stood with him amid still more clatter and churn.Sixty-seven percent of Republicans said they approved of the presidentâs response to the violence in Charlottesville last weekend, compared with just 10 percent of Democrats, according to a CBS News survey conducted over the past week.Itâs an indication of what now seems an almost immutable law of the Trump presidency. There are signs that Mr. Trumpâs support among Republican leaders and some Republican voters is weakening. But in an increasingly tribal America, with people on the left and the right getting information from different sources and seeing the same facts in different ways, it reflects the way Mr. Trump has become in many ways both symbol and chief agitator of a divided nation.Moral outrage at Mr. Trumpâs response to Charlottesville continues to glow white hot, but it has a largely partisan tinge.From Ms. Hicksâs perspective, the president simply pointed out a fact Leftists bore some responsibility for the violence, too. Of course, Nazis and white supremacists are bad, she said. But she does not believe Mr. Trump has any affinity for them. He said so himself. But she is exasperated that a significant part of the country seems to think otherwise. The weekâs frenzied headlines read to her like bulletins from another planet.âI feel like I am in a bizarro universe where no one but me is thinking logically,â she said. âWe have gone so off the rails of what this conversation is about.âMs. Hicks, who is black and grew up in Charlotte, N.C., welcomes the public soul-searching on the meaning of Confederate monuments. She believes that the statues were erected to intimidate black people and that they should be taken down. But instead of focusing on that, she sees opponents of Mr. Trump focusing on Mr. Trump.âThis is not about me as a black person, and my history,â she said. âThis is about this president and wanting to take him down because you donât like him.âMr. Bannonâs departure was more noise that didnât mean much, she said. âThe show is going to go on.âMuch of what powers the love for Mr. Trump among his core supporters is his boxerâs approach to the political class in Washington and to the news media, a group that in their eyes has approached them with a double standard and a sneering sense of superiority for years.Larry Laughlin, a retired businessman from a Minneapolis suburb, compares Mr. Trump to a high school senior who could âwalk up to the table with the jocks and the cheerleaders and put them in their place.â That is something that the ânerds and the losers, whose dads are unemployed and moms are working in the cafeteria,â could never do. Mr. Trump may be rich, he said, but actually belonged at the nerd table.âThe guys who wouldnât like me wouldnât like Trump,â he said. âThe guys who were condescending to him were condescending to me.âI feel like Iâm watching my uncle up there. Where me and Chuck Schumer â thatâs like going to the dentist,â he added, referring to the Democratic leader in the Senate.Gregory Kline, 46, a lawyer in Severna Park, Md., who is a Republican, said he did not vote for Mr. Trump but understands that part of the presidentâs support comes from fury at the left, particularly the media. When there is an attack by Muslim terrorists, for example, the media reaches for pundits who say most Muslims are good. But when it is a white supremacist, âevery conservative is lumped in with him,â he said.âItâs not that people are deaf and dumb and donât see it,â he said of Mr. Trumpâs sometimes erratic behavior. âItâs that they donât care. Iâve heard rational people I really respect make the craziest apologies for this president because they are sick of getting beat on and they are happy heâs fighting back.âIs there anything Mr. Trump could do that would change the minds of his supporters? For the most loyal, probably not. A recent Monmouth University poll found that, of the current 41 percent of Americans who approve of the job he is doing, 61 percent say they cannot see Mr. Trump doing anything that would make them disapprove of him. (A similar share of the other side says there is nothing Mr. Trump could do â other than resigning â to get them to like him.)But for many others, support is conditional. (Mr. Trumpâs poll numbers have dropped considerably since he took office in January.) Michael Dye, a 52-year-old engineer who is the treasurer for the Republican Party in Annapolis, Md., said he was âa bit stunnedâ that Mr. Trump had not focused more on condemning what was a large neo-Nazi march through the middle of the University of Virginia, Mr. Dyeâs alma mater.âAt best it is naÃ¯ve to think that the people showing up for the original protest were there simply because they were upset that this statue was being taken down,â said Mr. Dye, who said he voted reluctantly for Mr. Trump.Of the chant âJews will not replace us,â he said âYou can argue that it was 10 percent of the crowd. But there are those types in there and Iâve got a problem with that and I wish heâd specified that.âEven with his reservations, Mr. Dye said he would still vote for Mr. Trump. He wants his party to hold the reins and steer policy, and if Mr. Trump is the only route to that, he will take it.Partisanship is now so deep that what we see depends entirely on who is looking. So when Mr. Trump said there had been âviolence on both sides,â Democrats â and some Republicans â heard a dangerous moral equivalence between neo-Nazis and the people who opposed them. But for many Trump supporters, his words appealed to a basic sense of fairness.âAnyone who was fair-minded could see that there was violence on both sides,â said John McIntosh, 76, who lives in New Bern, N.C., and voted for Mr. Trump. He said that did not excuse the driver of the car that killed a counter protester and injured many others.When those who were horrified tried to convince those who were not, it did not go well.âEverybody is like, how can you not see it, heâs a total white supremacist, a total Nazi,â said Debra Skoog, a retired executive in Minneapolis and a lifelong Democrat who voted for Mr. Trump. âI just donât see it that way. I donât find his language as incriminating as some people do.âYascha Mounk, a political scientist at Harvard University who writes about democracy, said partisanship in the United States today is dangerously deep.âItâs now at a stage where a lot of Americans have such a loyalty to their political tribe that they are willing to go along with deeply undemocratic behavior,â he said. âIf their guy says, âI think we should push back the election for a few years because of a possible terrorist attack,â I fear that a significant part of the population would go along with it.âAnd in a polarized nation, many see a moment, full of passion on both sides, in which actions like taking down statues in the dead of night â as happened in Baltimore on Wednesday â are just bound to lead to more division.âPeople who see this stuff going down the memory hole as quickly as it is happening feel unsettled by it,â Mr. Kline said. âThe left doesnât realize that the reaction a lot of people would have is to sit back and say, âWait a minute, whatâs going on here?â âSource URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/19/us/politics/trump-supporters.html?partner=bloombergCredit SABRINA TAVERNISE

recommend.title: Bannon, Spain, Eclipse: Your Weekend Briefing
recommend.full_text: Here are the weekâs top stories, and a look ahead.1. The Spanish authorities said that the vehicular attacks that shattered Spainâs summer season appeared to be part of a sophisticated and far-reaching plot that could have resulted in far more devastation.Fourteen people were killed, and scores injured , in Barcelona and Cambrils. The Islamic State claimed responsibility for both assaults. At least four suspects have been arrested, but the search for the driver continues . Above, mourning the victims in Barcelona.The authorities linked both assaults to an explosion in Alcanar earlier in the week â a mistake by the plotters, they believe, who had intended to make a powerful truck bomb.Vehicles are increasingly being used as instruments of fear , stoking feelings that danger is everywhere.____2. Back in the United States , strife continued to churn.Steve Bannon, above, President Trumpâs chief strategist and a central player in Mr. Trumpâs election win, left his post at the White House . His departure could tip the Trump administration toward a more mainstream approach to issues like climate change, immigration, China and the war in Afghanistan.The announcement came as Mr. Trump faced backlash for his response to the violence in Charlottesville, Va., and just days after Mr. Bannon mockingly played down the American military threat to North Korea. News of Mr. Bannonâs departure was met with concern by conservatives and cheers on Wall Street. But around the country, many of Mr. Trumpâs supporters stood by him despite the tumultuous week.Mr. Bannon returned to Breitbart News , the right-wing website. âI can be more effective fighting from the outside,â he said. Here are the top officials in the Trump White House who have left .____3. The mother of Heather Heyer â the woman killed while demonstrating against white supremacists in Virginia â says she will not speak to President Trump .The president gave white supremacists an undeniable boost when he asserted that counterprotesters, whom he called âalt-left,â were as much to blame for the violence as neo-Nazis.The recent events have brought new attention to the coalition âantifa,â radical activists unafraid to scuffle with right-wing extremists. Terms like âantifaâ and âalt-leftâ are part of an extremist lexicon that has become important to understanding American politics.____4. On the heels of the Charlottesville violence, which began as a white nationalist rally against the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee, above, other U.S. cities are rushing to remove Confederate monuments .President Trump argued that the removal of Civil War-era statues was an assault on American culture, while others called for a national reckoning with Southern and American history . Artists and preservationists are also wading into the debate .On Saturday, thousands of demonstrators poured into the nationâs streets to denounce white supremacy. The epicenter appeared to be in Boston, where those attending a âfree speechâ rally that was feared to become a haven for neo-Nazis were outnumbered and overshadowed by counterprotesters. Neo-Nazis rallying in Berlin also met strong opposition.____5. Amid the upheaval, a surprising group is testing the moral compass of America  C.E.O.s. After President Trumpâs defense of white nationalist protesters, business executives â along with military leaders and other Republicans â rose to condemn hate groups .James Murdoch, the 21st Century Fox chief executive whose father, Rupert, is a frequent ally of Mr. Trumpâs, pledged $1 million to the Anti-Defamation League . And Mitt Romney, the 2012 Republican presidential nominee, said of the president  âWhether he intended to or not, what he communicated caused racists to rejoice.âOne business leader who has benefited from his Trump ties Stephen Schwarzman, whose Blackstone private equity group landed a major deal in Saudi Arabia after he started advising the president.Seeking a reset, Mr. Trump dined with a handful of his most generous donors, trying to build support for his hobbled legislative agenda .Also, the White House announced that he and the first lady, Melania, would skip this yearâs Kennedy Center Honors , only the fourth time a president will not attend.____6. Large-scale war games are set to begin on Monday. The joint exercises conducted twice a year by U.S. and South Korean troops are intended as preparation for a possible attack by North Korea , which said the drills this month were âkicking up war zeal.â Above, a military exercise in Pohang, South Korea, in April.With President Trump and North Koreaâs leader, Kim Jong-un, recently trading threats of nuclear war, some are asking whether the exercises could be used as a bargaining chip to persuade the North to freeze its weapons program.Residents of Seoul, the South Korean capital, which is firmly within range of North Korean artillery, are largely unshaken by the threat , our correspondent reports.____7. Letting âObamacare implode,â as President Trump has threatened, would cut off payments to insurers that help lower medical costs for millions. And doing so would send health insurance premiums spiking and the federal deficit soaring, the Congressional Budget Office said in a study that was requested by the House Democratic leader, Nancy Pelosi, above.And new research is provoking broad health concerns The sperm count of men in Western countries has been declining precipitously since 1973.____8. Hereâs how to watch .Ever wondered how civilizations around the world have understood solar eclipses? We looked into it.____9. The eclipse is expected to knock offline a big chunk of the solar power that currently provides one-tenth of Californiaâs electricity â giving grid operators a rare trial run for a future in which the nation is more reliant on renewable energy.In other climate news, two Senate Democrats are advocating a carbon tax plan that would cut the corporate tax rate as well as greenhouse gas emissions.And President Trump has signed a sweeping executive order to eliminate and streamline environmental regulations with the aim of speeding up infrastructure projects.____10. recommend.title: At Rally, Trump Blames Media for Countryâs Deepening Divisions
recommend.full_text: Correction AppendedPHOENIX â President Trump, stung by days of criticism that he sowed racial division in the United States after deadly clashes in Charlottesville, Va. , accused the news media on Tuesday of misrepresenting what he insisted was his prompt, unequivocal condemnation of bigotry and hatred.After declaring, âWhat happened in Charlottesville strikes at the core of America,â Mr. Trump delivered a lengthy, aggrieved defense of his statements after the Aug. 12 violence that left one woman dead and the nation reeling at the images of swastikas in Thomas Jeffersonâs hometown.Notably, he omitted blaming â both sides â for the violence as he had on Aug. 15. Those remarks had prompted intense criticism, including from fellow Republican leaders, for seeming to equate the hate groups and the protesters who turned out to oppose them.Removing his earlier statements about the Charlottesville violence from his jacket pocket, Mr. Trump on Tuesday glibly ticked off a list of racist groups that he had been urged to explicitly denounce, and ultimately did two days after the clashes. But he said the news media quoted him selectively, accused him of responding too late and ignored his message of unity.âI hit âem with neo-Nazi. I hit them with everything. I got the white supremacists, the neo-Nazi. I got them all in there. Letâs see. K.K.K., we have K.K.K.,â Mr. Trump said sardonically of his rebuke to Charlottesville racists, after being faulted for failing to condemn those groups in his initial response on the day of the clashes.Earlier Tuesday, Mr. Trump had traveled to a sun-scorched border post in Yuma, Ariz., to highlight his determination to crack down on illegal border crossings from Mexico. In Phoenix, the president threatened to shut down the federal government if his proposal to build a border wall is not funded.Mr. Trump also implied that he planned to pardon Joe Arpaio , the former sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., who became a national symbol of the crackdown on undocumented immigrants with round-âem-up searches that landed him in legal trouble. âWas Sheriff Joe convicted for doing his job?â Mr. Trump asked to wild whoops and cheers.âI wonât do it tonight because I donât want to cause any controversy,â Mr. Trump said. âIâll make a prediction I think heâs going to be just fine.âIn an angry, unbridled and unscripted performance that rivaled the most sulfurous rallies of his presidential campaign, Mr. Trump sought to deflect the anger toward him against the news media, suggesting that they, not he, were responsible for deepening divisions in the country.âItâs time to expose the crooked media deceptions,â Mr. Trump said. He added, âTheyâre very dishonest people.ââThe only people giving a platform to these hate groups is the media itself and the fake news,â he said.Mr. Trump also derided the media for focusing on his tweets , which are his preferred form of communication.âI donât do Twitter storms,â said the president, who often posts a few tweets in a row on a given subject, with exclamation points.It was the latest shift in what has become a nearly daily change of roles for this president from the statesmanlike commander in chief who sought harmony on Monday evening by citing the example of Americaâs soldiers to the political warrior who, just a day later, preached unapologetic division to his supporters here, eliciting louder cheers with every epithet.Returning repeatedly to Charlottesville, he said the news media failed to focus on anarchists, who he said turned out in their âhelmets and the black masks â Antifa,â Mr. Trump said, spitting out the nickname for the anti-fascist groups.Mr. Trump accused the news media of âtrying to take away our history and our heritage,â an apparent reference to the debate over removing statues to heroes of the Confederacy, which prompted the rally by neo-Nazis and white supremacists in Charlottesville.The president singled out a familiar list of malefactors â including the âfailing New York Times,â which he erroneously said had apologized for its coverage of the 2016 election; CNN; and The Washington Post, which he described as a lobbying arm for Amazon, the company controlled by the newspaperâs owner, Jeff Bezos.Pointing repeatedly to the cameras in the middle of a cavernous convention center, Mr. Trump whipped the crowd into fevered chants of âCNN Sucks.â Members of the audience shouted epithets at reporters, some demanding that the news media stop tormenting the president with questions about his ties to Russia.The people in Arizona on Mr. Trumpâs enemies list include both of the stateâs Republican senators Jeff Flake, a longtime nemesis whom Mr. Trump has described as âtoxic,â not to mention a âflakeâ; and John McCain, who cast the decisive Republican vote in the Senate to dash Mr. Trumpâs effort to repeal President Barack Obamaâs Affordable Care Act.His voice thick with sarcasm, Mr. Trump said he had been instructed not to mention either of the senators by name. Of Mr. Flake, he said, âNobody knows who the hell he is.â Of Mr. McCain, he repeated over and over, âOne vote,â which cost Republicans health care.Mr. Trump recited a familiar litany of complaints about lawless immigrants and naÃ¯ve trade deals. But aside from a reference to renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico â he said he expected he would have to terminate the accord first â the speech was light on policy specifics.At another point, he heralded the arrival of clean coal plants, adding, âThey are taking out coal; they are going to clean itâ â which is not how clean coal plants function.Mr. Trump also said little about foreign policy, offering only a bare summary of the Afghanistan policy he unveiled on Monday night , and suggesting that North Koreaâs dictator, Kim Jong-un, had retreated in the face of Mr. Trumpâs threats of military action against him.The president made no mention of the accident involving the Navy destroyer John S. McCain , named for the grandfather and father of Senator McCain, which left several sailors presumed dead.Hours earlier, Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, had said that Mr. Trump would not issue a pardon for Mr. Arpaio on Tuesday. Mr. Arpaio was found guilty of criminal contempt of court after he flouted an order to stop detaining people his office suspected of being undocumented immigrants.He said in an interview on Tuesday night that he did not know Mr. Trump was going to mention his name at the rally and reiterated that he had not talked to the president since last fall. But Mr. Arpaio said he âwasnât really surprisedâ to hear he would likely be pardoned.âI just know him,â Mr. Arpaio said of the president. âAnd even though everybody said heâs not going to talk about it â deep in my heart, I knew he was going to say something. I had no hints, but thatâs who he is.âMr. Trumpâs teased pardon of Mr. Arpaio energized the crowd at the convention center, where the president had been expected to stick to a theme of national unity. Even so, the forum drew scores of protesters and fanned fears of arousing more of the ugly nativist sentiments that exploded more than a week ago in Charlottesville .Outside the convention center, the scene was a tense caldron, with hundreds of people screaming at one another, chanting slogans and hoisting placards that said âFire Trumpâ and âFake President.â Some voiced fears about the potential for the repeat of the violence that broke out in Charlottesville, while others griped about the 108-degree heat in Phoenix.At one point, as Mr. Trump defended his remarks about the unrest in Charlottesville, protesters interrupted.âHow did he get in here?â Mr. Trump said. âHeâs supposed to be with the few people outside.âArizona was the site of one of Mr. Trumpâs most raucous rallies during the presidential campaign, and if anything, the atmosphere was even more charged on this visit, his first as president. The Democratic mayor of Phoenix, Greg Stanton, pleaded with Mr. Trump to put off his trip, saying it would only aggravate racial tensions, coming so soon after clashes between white supremacists and counterprotesters in Virginia.This article has been revised to reflect the following correction An article on Wednesday about President Trumpâs rally in Phoenix referred incorrectly in some copies to the destroyer John S. McCain. It was named for Senator John McCainâs grandfather and father â John S. McCain Sr. and John S. McCain Jr., both Navy admirals; it was not named after the Arizona senator.Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/us/politics/trump-rally-arizona.html?partner=bloombergCredit MARK LANDLER and MAGGIE HABERMAN

recommend.title: Business Groups Court White House Even After C.E.O. Defections
recommend.full_text: Last Wednesday, even as top executives were abandoning President Trumpâs business advisory councils after his remarks on white supremacist violence in Charlottesville, Va., other industry leaders were busy making their interests known to a business-friendly White House.Jerry Howard, chief executive of the National Association of Home Builders, a trade group, traveled to the Eisenhower Executive Office Building to meet with Mark Calabria, the chief economist to Vice President Mike Pence. The men talked tax reform, and Mr. Howard pressed for incentives including the mortgage interest deduction.It was the kind of back and forth that goes on between business interests and the administration every day. And that relative normalcy â even on a day when a number of prominent C.E.O.s publicly abandoned Mr. Trump â served as a reminder that no matter the presidentâs missteps, his top legislative priorities, particularly tax reform, still draw strong support from business leaders.Now, with some signs that the worst fallout from Mr. Trumpâs response to Charlottesville has passed â and with the departure of Stephen K. Bannon, Mr. Trumpâs volatile strategist â some in the business community are voicing hope that the administration can tackle tax reform.âEveryone is similarly motivated to reach some version of success, to get a tax bill to the presidentâs desk that he can sign,â said Rohit Kumar, a tax specialist at PricewaterhouseCoopers. âOn tax, thereâs a lot of business community support, thereâs a lot of similar incentives.âEfforts to overhaul the tax code are expected to begin in earnest this fall. Already, big business groups are lining up to support the White Houseâs efforts.The Business Roundtable, which represents chief executives of the largest companies, has started an advertising campaign calling for a tax overhaul that is supported by the White House, the Treasury Department and Republican congressional leadership.Such coordination between industry groups and the White House stands in contrast to last weekâs unraveling of the business advisory groups, but confirms what many in the corporate world say Behind the scenes, there is still active dialogue between business groups and the administration.âWe have had broad access to the administration and cabinet members,â said Mr. Howard, who has been in associations and lobbying groups for 30 years. âOur access, and their receptivity to our requests for meetings, has been better than Iâve ever seen.âFour people in particular have emerged as go-to contacts for executives and lobbyists seeking to sway the debate Gary D. Cohn, director of the National Economic Council; Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin; Deputy National Security Adviser Dina Powell; and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross.All four are familiar faces to business leaders. Mr. Cohn, Mr. Mnuchin and Ms. Powell are alumni of Goldman Sachs, the powerful investment bank, and Mr. Ross ran a private equity firm.Expectations of a more stable partnership with business appeared to hearten investors. The major stock market indexes rose sharply on Tuesday, in part buoyed by investor hopes that with the departure of Mr. Bannon, more pragmatic voices within the administration will gain strength, possibly resulting in a tax overhaul bill. The benchmark Standard & Poorâs 500-stock index closed up nearly 1 percent, its biggest gain in a week.âI think investors are picking up on this,â said Jim Paulsen, a stock market strategist for the Leuthold Group, an investment firm based in Minneapolis. âWe now have people around the president who are more moderate and pro-business, like Gary Cohn.âMr. Paulsen also suggested that Mr. Trumpâs measured speech on Monday about sending more troops to Afghanistan could be seen by those still willing to bet on the Trump economy that there is now âchange within the administration.âEven as corporate leaders criticized the president, industry representatives and lobbyists have continued to press various agencies in Mr. Trumpâs administration. At the Environmental Protection Agency, industry groups have attained significant influence as Scott Pruitt, the E.P.A.âs administrator, has rolled back regulations .Still, repairing relations with the White House itself will take time. While the Business Roundtable is supporting efforts for tax reform, its chairman, Jamie Dimon , the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, has joined the chorus of leaders criticizing Mr. Trump last week.âI strongly disagree with President Trumpâs reaction to the events that took place in Charlottesville over the past several days,â Mr. Dimon wrote on Twitter .The schism between Mr. Trump and top chief executives is real, and could have meaningful implications.Former White House officials and executives said that while it is useful for executives to interact with cabinet-level officials and members of the vice presidentâs staff, such relationships are no substitute to a working relationship with the Oval Office.âYou will see a lot of connecting points at the cabinet level, and thatâs natural and good,â said Mack McLarty, President Bill Clintonâs first chief of staff. âBut at the end of the day, the president is going to make the final decision on policies and how legislation is approached. So there has got to be some ability for businesses, hopefully large and small, to engage with this administration, as there was such great promise going in.âThere are even questions about whether or not the executives who once made up his advisory councils will be willing to speak out in support of causes they shared with the White House, including a tax code overhaul.âFor this president, losing both councils is terrifically challenging,â said Richard Levick, founder of the Washington public relations firm Levick. âThey were more than symbolic. These C.E.O.s were going to be the ambassadors for the administration to talk about tax reform, about health care reform , about infrastructure.âAnd there are other issues where business interests and the wishes of the White House diverge.Mr. Trumpâs nominee to lead the Export-Import Bank, which supports American exports, is facing stiff opposition from business groups.The nominee, Scott Garrett, a former congressman from New Jersey once said Ex-Im, as it is known, âembodies the corruption of the free enterprise system.âThat has rattled big companies such as Boeing, General Electric and Caterpillar, which rely on Ex-Im to help finance their overseas sales.Now, as the prospect of hearings and a confirmation vote on Mr. Garrettâs appointment draw closer, big business groups have stepped up their efforts to quash his nomination. The National Association of Manufacturers is leading a campaign to drum up opposition to Mr. Garrett.And the Business Roundtable spoke out against Mr. Garrett on Twitter, writing âBRT cannot support Scott Garrett or any #ExIm nominee who does not demonstrate strong support for the bank and commitment to get it promptly back to work, fully executing its mission.âIt is not clear if Mr. Garrett will lead Ex-Im, or if the efforts to derail his nomination will succeed. But even if big companies are able to sway the administration on the Ex-Im leadership, and even if a tax overhaul is enacted, it may be some time before corporate chieftains want to sit alongside Mr. Trump again.âOur clients were coming to me eight months ago and saying, âWhat if we are the victims of a nasty Trump tweet?ââ Mr. Levick said. âNow theyâre saying, âWhat do we do if the president wants a photo op?â You donât want to be seen with this president.âSource URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/business/white-house-ceos.html?partner=bloombergCredit DAVID GELLES

recommend.title: McConnell, in Private, Doubts if Trump Can Save Presidency
recommend.full_text: The relationship between President Trump and Senator Mitch McConnell , the majority leader, has disintegrated to the point that they have not spoken to each other in weeks, and Mr. McConnell has privately expressed uncertainty that Mr. Trump will be able to salvage his administration after a series of summer crises.What was once an uneasy governing alliance has curdled into a feud of mutual resentment and sometimes outright hostility, complicated by the position of Mr. McConnellâs wife, Elaine L. Chao, in Mr. Trumpâs cabinet, according to more than a dozen people briefed on their imperiled partnership. Angry phone calls and private badmouthing have devolved into open conflict, with the president threatening to oppose Republican senators who cross him, and Mr. McConnell mobilizing to their defense.The rupture between Mr. Trump and Mr. McConnell comes at a highly perilous moment for Republicans, who face a number of urgent deadlines when they return to Washington next month. Congress must approve new spending measures and raise the statutory limit on government borrowing within weeks of reconvening, and Republicans are hoping to push through an elaborate rewrite of the federal tax code. There is scant room for legislative error on any front.A protracted government shutdown or a default on sovereign debt could be disastrous â for the economy and for the party that controls the White House and both chambers of Congress.Yet Mr. Trump and Mr. McConnell are locked in a political cold war. Neither man would comment for this article. Don Stewart, a spokesman for Mr. McConnell, noted that the senator and the president had âshared goals,â and pointed to âtax reform, infrastructure, funding the government, not defaulting on the debt, passing the defense authorization bill.âStill, the back-and-forth has been dramatic.In a series of tweets this month, Mr. Trump criticized Mr. McConnell publicly, and berated him in a phone call that quickly devolved into a profane shouting match.During the call, which Mr. Trump initiated on Aug. 9 from his New Jersey golf club, the president accused Mr. McConnell of bungling the health care issue. He was even more animated about what he intimated was the Senate leaderâs refusal to protect him from investigations of Russian interference in the 2016 election, according to Republicans briefed on the conversation.Mr. McConnell has fumed over Mr. Trumpâs regular threats against fellow Republicans and criticism of Senate rules, and questioned Mr. Trumpâs understanding of the presidency in a public speech. Mr. McConnell has made sharper comments in private, describing Mr. Trump as entirely unwilling to learn the basics of governing.In offhand remarks, Mr. McConnell has expressed a sense of bewilderment about where Mr. Trumpâs presidency may be headed, and has mused about whether Mr. Trump will be in a position to lead the Republican Party into next yearâs elections and beyond, according to people who have spoken to him directly.While maintaining a pose of public reserve, Mr. McConnell expressed horror to advisers last week after Mr. Trumpâs comments equating white supremacists in Charlottesville, Va., with protesters who rallied against them. Mr. Trumpâs most explosive remarks came at a news conference in Manhattan, where he stood beside Ms. Chao, the transportation secretary. (Ms. Chao, deflecting a question about the tensions between her husband and the president she serves, told reporters, âI stand by my man â both of them.â)Mr. McConnell signaled to business leaders that he was deeply uncomfortable with Mr. Trumpâs comments Several who resigned advisory roles in the Trump administration contacted Mr. McConnellâs office after the fact, and were told that Mr. McConnell fully understood their choices, three people briefed on the conversations said.Mr. Trump has also continued to badger and threaten Mr. McConnellâs Senate colleagues, including Senator Jeff Flake of Arizona, whose Republican primary challenger was praised by Mr. Trump last week .At a campaign rally in Phoenix on Tuesday, Mr. Trump alluded to Mr. Flake unfavorably, referring to him as âweak on bordersâ and âweak on crimeâ without mentioning him by name. He referred to Mr. McConnell only in passing, calling on him to abolish the Senate filibuster .Senior Republican officials said before the rally that they would stand up for Mr. Flake against any attacks. A Republican â super PAC â aligned with Mr. McConnell released a web ad on Tuesday assailing Ms. Ward as a fringe-dwelling conspiracy theorist.[Video "ChemtrailKelli," an attack ad released by a Republican âsuper PACâ aligned with Mr. McConnell. Watch on YouTube. ]âWhen it comes to the Senate, thereâs an Article 5 understanding An attack against one is an attack against all,â said Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, who has found himself in Mr. Trumpâs sights many times, invoking the NATO allianceâs mutual defense doctrine.The fury among Senate Republicans toward Mr. Trump has been building since last month, even before he lashed out at Mr. McConnell. Some of them blame the president for not being able to rally the party around any version of legislation to repeal the Affordable Care Act, accusing him of not knowing even the basics about the policy. Senate Republicans also say strong-arm tactics from the White House backfired, making it harder to cobble together votes and have left bad feelings in the caucus.When Mr. Trump addressed a Boy Scouts jamboree last month in West Virginia, White House aides told Senator Shelley Moore Capito, a Republican from the state whose support was in doubt, that she could only accompany him on Air Force One if she committed to voting for the health care bill. She declined the invitation, noting that she could not commit to voting for a measure she had not seen, according to a Republican briefed on the conversation.Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska told colleagues that when Mr. Trumpâs interior secretary threatened to pull back federal funding for her state, she felt boxed in and unable to vote for the health care bill.In a show of solidarity, albeit one planned well before Mr. Trump took aim at Mr. Flake, Mr. McConnell will host a $1,000-per-person dinner on Friday in Kentucky for the Arizona senator, as well as for Senator Dean Heller of Nevada, who is also facing a Trump-inspired primary race next year, and Senator Deb Fischer of Nebraska. Mr. Flake is expected to attend the event.Former Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire, a Republican who is close to Mr. McConnell, said frustration with Mr. Trump was boiling over in the chamber. Mr. Gregg blamed the president for undermining congressional leaders, and said the House and Senate would have to govern on their own if Mr. Trump âcanât participate constructively.ââFailure to do things like keeping the government open and passing a tax bill is the functional equivalent of playing Russian roulette with all the chambers loaded,â Mr. Gregg said.Others in the party divide blame between Mr. Trump and Mr. McConnell. Al Hoffman, a former finance chairman of the Republican National Committee who has been supportive of Mr. McConnell, said Mr. McConnell was culpable because he has failed to deliver legislative victories. âUltimately, itâs been Mitchâs responsibility, and I donât think heâs done much,â Mr. Hoffman said.But Mr. Hoffman predicted that Mr. McConnell would likely outlast the president.âI think heâs going to blow up, self-implode,â Mr. Hoffman said of Mr. Trump. âI wouldnât be surprised if McConnell pulls back his support of Trump and tries to go it alone.âAn all-out clash between Mr. Trump and Mr. McConnell would play out between men whose strengths and weaknesses are very different. Mr. Trump is a political amateur, still unschooled in the ways of Washington, but he maintains a viselike grip on the affections of the Republican base. Mr. McConnell is a soft-spoken career politician, with virtuoso mastery of political fund-raising and tactics, but he had no mass following to speak of.Mr. McConnell, while baffled at Mr. Trumpâs penchant for internecine attacks, is a ruthless pragmatist and has given no overt indication that he plans to seek more drastic conflict. Despite his private battles with Mr. Trump, Mr. McConnell has sent reassuring signals with his public conduct On Monday, he appeared in Louisville, Ky., with Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, for a discussion of tax policy.Mr. McConnellâs Senate colleagues, however, have grown bolder. The combination of the presidentâs frontal attacks on Senate Republicans and his claim that there were âfine peopleâ marching with white supremacists in Charlottesville has emboldened lawmakers to criticize Mr. Trump in withering terms.Senator Bob Corker of Tennessee rebuked Mr. Trump last week for failing to âdemonstrate the stability nor some of the competenceâ required of presidents. On Monday, Senator Susan Collins of Maine said in a television interview that she was uncertain Mr. Trump would be the Republican presidential nominee in 2020.There are few recent precedents for the rift. The last time a president turned on a legislative leader of his own party was in 2002, when allies of George W. Bush helped force Trent Lott to step down as Senate minority leader after racially charged remarks at a birthday party for Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina.For the moment, Mr. McConnell appears to be far more secure in his position, and perhaps immune to coercion from the White House. Republicans are unlikely to lose control of the Senate in 2018, and Mr. Trump has no allies in the Senate who have shown an appetite for combat with Mr. McConnell.Still, some allies of Mr. Trump on the right â including Stephen K. Bannon, who stepped down last week as Mr. Trumpâs chief strategist â welcome more direct conflict with Mr. McConnell and congressional Republicans.Roger J. Stone Jr., a Republican strategist who has advised Mr. Trump for decades, said the president needed to âtake a scalpâ in order to force cooperation from Republican elites who have resisted his agenda. Mr. Stone urged Mr. Trump to make an example of one or more Republicans, like Mr. Flake, who have refused to give full support to his administration.âThe president should start bumping off incumbent Republican members of Congress in primaries,â Mr. Stone said. âIf he did that, Mitch McConnell and Paul Ryan would wet their pants and the rest of the Republicans would get in line.âBut Mr. McConnellâs allies warn that the president should be wary of doing anything that could jeopardize the Senate Republican majority.âThe quickest way for him to get impeached is for Trump to knock off Jeff Flake and Dean Heller and be faced with a Democrat-led Senate,â said Billy Piper, a lobbyist and former McConnell chief of staff.Get politics and Washington news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter .Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/22/us/politics/mitch-mcconnell-trump.html?partner=bloombergCredit ALEXANDER BURNS and JONATHAN MARTIN

recommend.title: Different Day, Different Audience, and a Completely Different Trump
recommend.full_text: RENO, Nev. â President Trump reverted to his script as commander in chief here on Wednesday.The morning after he delivered an aggrieved and impromptu defense of his comments on the violence in Charlottesville , Va., Mr. Trump spoke in a more measured tone to the national convention of the American Legion, telling its members that âwe are not defined by the color of our skin,â and that the country will overcome its challenges by reaffirming its common values.âWe are here to hold you up as an example of strength, courage and resolve that our country will need to overcome the many challenges that we face,â the president said, speaking slowly and gravely as he read from a teleprompter. âWe are here to draw inspiration from you as we seek to renew the bonds of loyalty that bind us together as one people and one nation.âIt was a day-and-night contrast to Mr. Trumpâs performance Tuesday night in Phoenix , where he lurched from subject to subject and accused the news media of ignoring what he insisted had been his message of unity in the aftermath of Charlottesville.But such contrasts have become a recurring motif of his presidency Mr. Trump has toggled between Teleprompter Trump and Unplugged Trump every day since the deadly clashes in Virginia, leaving Washington and the rest of the nation with a chronic case of rhetorical whiplash.The split speaking personality is not new. Mr. Trump spent years mocking President Barack Obama for using a teleprompter.But ever since Mr. Trump won his first round of primaries and his path toward the Republican presidential nomination became likelier, his family members and some supporters have urged him â not with a lot of success â to professionalize his performances, and to try to avoid the dangers of the kind of spontaneous remarks he made in Arizona.There were obvious differences between the venue and audience for the Phoenix speech and those here on Wednesday. The first was a campaign-style rally for his most boisterous supporters, against a thumping soundtrack of the Rolling Stones; the second was an official presidential event for an audience of veterans, complete with a bill-signing ceremony.There were many reasons to believe that the presidentâs angry performance in Phoenix was the real Donald J. Trump . It was consistent with the way he has reacted to all sorts of setbacks since he took office, including the Senateâs failure to repeal the Affordable Care Act and the multiple investigations of his links to Russia.His advisers had actually anticipated the possibility that he would go off-script after The New York Times reported earlier Tuesday on his toxic relationship with Senator Mitch McConnell , Republican of Kentucky and the majority leader. The article was referred to frequently on the cable television shows that the president likes to watch.While reporters declared his rally one of his most caustic in the past two years, some White House aides said privately on Wednesday that they found some comfort in the fact that it could have been worse.Many presidents, of course, have complained bitterly behind closed doors about their treatment at the hands of the news media or their political opponents. Robert Dallek, a historian, said Franklin D. Roosevelt lashed out at the news media with his aides, while John F. Kennedy canceled a White House subscription to The New York Herald Tribune after a string of negative coverage.âThere was a difference between how they performed in public and private,â Mr. Dallek said.The difference with Mr. Trump, he said, is that the president not only vents those feelings publicly, but also makes that venting a central part of his message.In Phoenix, Mr. Trump did not so much depart from his prepared text as ball it up and toss it into a wastebasket. After speaking perfunctorily about the need for Americans to love one another â words borrowed from his somber, teleprompter-guided Afghanistan address to troops in Virginia on Monday night â Mr. Trump went off message. Placing blame on the news media, he delivered a discursive, defensive analysis of why he was not responsible for dividing Americans.Mr. Trump threw in a few asides in his speech to the American Legion. Promoting legislation that he said would improve medical care for veterans and make the system more accountable, Mr. Trump promised that if the care did not improve, he would have one response to the people providing it âYouâre fired.âHe also elaborated on the Afghanistan strategy he unveiled Monday âWe will give our men and women in uniform the tools they need and the trust they have earned to fight and to win.âAnd he promoted investments in missile defense, which he said would deter aggressive government overseas.But for the most part, Mr. Trumpâs focus remained on veterans.He got a polite welcome from the audience at the Reno-Sparks Convention Center, though the group had made clear it did not share his ambivalent response to the clashes between neo-Nazis and white supremacists and counterprotesters in Charlottesville.On Monday, the Legion reaffirmed a 1923 resolution condemning any individual or group that âcreates, or fosters racial, religious or class strife among our people, or which takes into their own hands the enforcement of law, determination of guilt, or infliction of punishment.âAt the event, Mr. Trump signed into law bipartisan legislation that overhauls the federal governmentâs disability benefits appeals procedure for veterans.About half a million veterans have pending claims contesting a Veterans Benefits Administration decision, many of which can take years to sort out. The new law is expected to substantially speed up that process by creating separate queues for veterans based on the evidence they wish to submit with their claims.Mr. Trump also introduced a Medal of Honor recipient, Donald E. Ballard, who declared that the president was the right leader to âdrain the swamp.âMr. Trump laughed and said of Mr. Ballardâs impromptu remark âThatâs very risky of me. That could ruin the whole day for me.âBut in Mr. Trumpâs view, it is the teleprompter â and any form of precanned remarks â that have long been the enemy. And it is true that his most memorable remarks have come without it.When he launched his campaign in 2015 , Mr. Trump almost instantly tossed aside his prepared speech, and instead went on a nearly hourlong riff about immigration, about the United States being taken advantage of and about Mexico not sending âtheir bestâ to the country.âTheyâre bringing crime. Theyâre rapists,â Mr. Trump said, before adding that he assumed âsomeâ Mexicans were âgood people.âWhen he brought on Paul Manafort as his campaign chairman in May 2016, one of Mr. Manafortâs first orders of business was to get the candidate to adjust to teleprompters. But when word leaked out that Mr. Manafort told a closed-door meeting of Republican National Committee donors that he was working on scaling back some of Mr. Trumpâs more caustic remarks, the candidate publicly rebuffed those efforts.âI sort of donât like toning it down,â Mr. Trump told a crowd in Connecticut shortly afterward. âIsnât it nice that Iâm not one of these teleprompter guys?âGet politics and Washington news updates via Facebook , Twitter and the Morning Briefing newsletter .Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/23/us/politics/trump-speech-reno-phoenix.html?partner=bloombergCredit MARK LANDLER

recommend.title: Gary Cohn, Trumpâs Adviser, Said to Have Drafted Resignation Letter After Charlottesville
recommend.full_text: Gary D. Cohn, the director of the White House Economic Council, wrote a resignation letter after President Trump blamed âboth sidesâ in the deadly protest this month against a Charlottesville, Va., rally by white supremacists and neo-Nazis, according to three people familiar with the document.Mr. Cohn ultimately changed his mind and decided in recent days to remain on as Mr. Trumpâs chief economic adviser, said one person familiar with his thinking.But in a stunning critique of the president, Mr. Cohn told The Financial Times in an interview published on Friday that the Trump administration âcan and must do betterâ to condemn hate groups and âdo everything we can to heal the deep divisions that exist in our communities.âMr. Cohn is an architect of a broad set of tax reforms that the White House hopes will deliver the first legislative victory of Mr. Trumpâs tumultuous administration. The president next week will travel to Springfield, Mo., in a push to sell the tax reform package.But Mr. Cohn was anguished, according to a friend and two other people familiar with his thinking, by Mr. Trumpâs remarks after the Aug. 12 violence that resulted in the death of a 32-year-old woman who was protesting neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan demonstrators in Charlottesville.On Aug. 15, Mr. Cohn stood nearby in the lobby of Trump Tower, where the president told reporters there also were âvery fine people on both sidesâ of the Charlottesville rally. After Mr. Trump left, Mr. Cohn stood uncomfortably fielding questions about the presidentâs statements, and he repeatedly declined to comment.He debated for over a week with his wife and friends on whether to quit, according to the people familiar with his thinking. This week, Mr. Cohn decided to remain in his job, believing he could be more effective as a public servant inside the White House than out of it.He is one of the few Jewish members in the administration who have publicly condemned Mr. Trumpâs remarks about Charlottesville, although he has quietly disagreed with the president on a number of policy matters.As Mr. Trump stood by his equivocal comments on Charlottesville and business leaders left presidential advisory panels in protest, Mr. Cohn told The Financial Times, he felt âenormous pressureâ to step down. Various friends, and Mr. Cohnâs wife, were at one point among those who were urging him to resign, said several people familiar with their advice.A senior administration official said the president was not surprised by Mr. Cohnâs remarks to The Financial Times. Another official said the sentiments had been relayed clearly to Mr. Trump, and Mr. Cohn had said that if asked, he would say how he felt.But on Friday, Roger Stone, a longtime adviser to Mr. Trump, tweeted that Mr. Cohn âshould be fired immediately for his public attack on the president.â In his tweet, Mr. Stone misspelled the name of Mr. Cohn, whom he has aggressively criticized, and said the economic adviser was ârecommended for his White House job by Jared Kushner.âIt is highly unusual for a senior member of any presidential administration to publicly discuss the possibility of stepping down. Geoff Garin, a veteran Democratic pollster who worked on Hillary Clintonâs 2008 presidential campaign, said even though Mr. Cohn did not criticize Mr. Trump by name in the Financial Times interview, âthe comments are still very tough and very blunt, including his comments about the push-and-pull whether to stay and whether to go.ââThereâs no effort to conceal the fact that what Trump said was wrong and troubling,â Mr. Garin said. âAnd itâs hard to think of very many precedents for somebody like that who is a high-ranking presidential adviser.âMr. Cohn told The Financial Times that âas a Jewish American, I will not allow neo-Nazis ranting âJews will not replace usâ to cause this Jew to leave his job.âBut the job has not been easy. For Mr. Cohn, said two people familiar with his thinking, every day at the White House requires a different calculus over how best to spend his political capital. Right now, these people said, he will focus on economic policies that he believes are essential to the stability of the markets and the United States work force â even when other issues worry him.Nudging Mr. Trump toward a more free-trade stance that avoids harsh steps toward China and other economic partners is paramount, these people said. Part of that, they added, is opposing tariffs on steel, aluminum and other goods that might damage relationships with American allies.But using political capital on those fights means avoiding others, even when the president espouses policies that run contrary to Mr. Cohnâs own principles, the two people said. Among other things, they said, Mr. Cohn disagrees with the presidentâs directive banning transgender people from joining the military, but will leave that fight to others.On Aug. 17, with word of Mr. Cohnâs unhappiness percolating on Wall Street, some traders and investors got jittery. Seeing Mr. Cohn as a key player in pushing forward the Trump administrationâs tax cuts, some sold American stocks, pushing prices down.Mr. Cohn, a onetime silver trader who eventually became president of Goldman Sachs, was struck by the market move, said two people familiar with his thinking. He continued to huddle with friends and family over what steps to take, attending meetings in Washington during the process.At some point during the past 10 days, Mr. Cohn penned a tentative resignation letter, said the three people familiar with the draft. It was not immediately clear what day the letter was written, or if Mr. Trump was ever made aware of it.But during a private Aug. 18 meeting with the president at his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., Mr. Cohn relayed his concerns about Mr. Trumpâs comments on Charlottesville, said people with knowledge of the gathering. The exact details of the talk are not clear, but the president urged Mr. Cohn to stay.âI have had numerous private conversations with the president on this topic,â Mr. Cohn told The Financial Times, adding that âI have not been bashful saying what I think.âOne possible part of Mr. Cohnâs calculus is the chance that he could be named Federal Reserve chairman early next year, a move Mr. Trump has said he is considering. Mr. Cohn has in the past expressed interest in the job, said two people close to him. But unlike past Fed chairmen, Mr. Cohn is not an economist, and some of his friends have said it is hard to imagine him in the more reserved, less dynamic environment of the Fed, which would be a huge contrast to the pace of Goldman Sachs or the White House.Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, who also is Jewish, defended Mr. Trump in a statement a week ago, after more than 300 of his Yale classmates urged him in a letter to step down. At a briefing with reporters at the White House on Friday, Mr. Mnuchin, an old business partner of Mr. Trump who has at times clashed over policy with Mr. Cohn, told reporters that under no circumstances has he considered resigning.Source URL https//www.nytimes.com/2017/08/25/us/politics/gary-cohn-trump-charlottesville.html?partner=bloombergCredit KATE KELLY and MAGGIE HABERMAN
